Graphical abstract The Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits promising bifunctional catalytic activity towards ORR and OER. Most important of all, the ORR catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be enhanced by the doping of Cu, and the OER catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be improved by the doping of Se. Developing highly efficient and nonprecious electrocatalysts for oxygen-involving energy conversion reactions is crucial for the development of clean and sustainable energy technologies. Herein, the intrinsic relationship between the atomic structure and the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 was investigated based on density functional theory. It was found that the Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits promising bifunctional catalytic activity towards the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The ORR catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be enhanced by the doping of Cu, and the OER catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be improved by the doping of Se. Furthermore, a descriptor derived from the electron affinity was developed, which correlate Ni3S2 microstructures with their catalytic activities. This study provides a systematic understanding to the intrinsic activity of transition metal sulfides, paving the way to the rational design and development of advanced electrocatalysts for renewable energy technology. Keywords Density functional theory Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Bifunctional catalysis Nickle sulfide 1 Introduction Due to the rapid depletion of fossil fuels and increasing global warming issues, it is exigent to develop highly efficient and sustainable alternative energy-storage and conversion technologies, such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries and water splitting. Among these technologies, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the most important electrochemical reactions [1–4]. However, the sluggish kinetics of both ORR and OER and the high overpotentials greatly limit their practical application [1,2]. At present, noble Pt metal and Ir/Ru-based oxides are the benchmark electrocatalysts to speed up the ORR and OER, respectively. However, the large-scale application of these precious electrocatalysts is seriously restricted by their low natural abundance and high cost. Therefore, over the past few years, significant research effort has been devoted to investigate non-noble electrocatalysts with excellent catalytic activities for ORR and OER [5–7]. Over the past decade, various candidates have been explored as alternatives to the noble metal-based catalysts for ORR and OER, such as heteroatom-doped carbon materials, metal N4-macrocycles, and transition metal oxides and sulfides [6,8–11]. These new catalysts not only are efficient but also avoid the use of scarce materials. Among these materials, transition metal sulfides have received great attention due to their unique electronic structure, good electrical conductivity, low cost, and good durability [12–18]. Wang et al. synthesized a Co1-xS/RGO (reduced graphene oxide) hybrid material by a mild solution-phase reaction followed by a solid-state annealing step [19]. They found that the Co1-xS/RGO hybrid showed high ORR catalytic activity both in acid and basic solutions, which results from the intimate coupling between Co1-xS nanoparticles and RGO [19]. Fei et al. found that FexNi3-xS2@Ni foam exhibited an excellent OER and HER bifunctional catalytic activity, and remarkable stability [20]. The incorporated Fe cations significantly modulate the morphology and the surface electron density of Ni3S2, and then significantly boost the electrochemical activity [20]. Wang et al. synthesized a series of lattice-strained homogeneous NiSxSe1-x nanosheet@nanorods hybrids and found NiS0.5Se0.5 with nearly 2.7 % lattice strain exhibits outstanding activity for OER and HER with low overpotentials of 70 and 257 mV at 10 ma/cm2 [21]. Ganesan et al. developed a novel and facile synthesis of CoS2 nanoparticles grown in situ on N, S-doped graphene oxide (GO) as a highly efficient oxygen electrode for both OER and ORR. CoS2/N,S-GO showed an outstanding oxygen electrode activity with a potential of 0.82 V against a reversible hydrogen electrode in alkaline medium [22]. Although prominent progress has been made, developing high activity and cost-effective catalysts for ORR and OER based on transition metal sulfides remains a significant challenge to date [18]. The major obstacle is the lack of the intrinsic relationship between the catalytic activity and the detailed atomic structure. Due to the rich forms of transition metal sulfides, the effect of the atomic and electronic structures of metal sulfides on the catalytic activity of the ORR and OER remains to be clarified. It is crucial and imperative to investigate the intrinsic relationship between the ORR/OER catalytic activity and the intrinsic material characteristics. The development of design principles that correlate the intrinsic material properties to the catalytic activity will accelerate the search for high activity catalysts based on earth-abundant and cost-effective materials. Among various transition metal sulfides, Ni3S2 is one the most metal-rich members and possesses a continuous network of Ni3-triangles connected by Ni-Ni bonds in the crystal structure and exhibits good metallic properties, which contributes to the remarkable electrical conductivity and electrochemical performance [23–28]. Previous density functional theory (DFT) work has proved that the heazlewoodite N3S2 is a rather conventional metal with marginal electron-electron correlation effect [29]. Among the bulk phases of Ni x S y (NiS2, Ni3S4, Ni9S10, NiS, Ni9S8, Ni3S2, Ni2S and Ni3S), Ni3S2 is relatively stable when the chemical potential (Δμ s) of S ranges from −0.97 to −0.41 eV [30]. Qin et al. found that the introduction of P atoms can modify the electronic structure of Ni3S2, optimize the HER Gibbs free energy, change water adsorption strength and reduce the barrier of water dissociation [31]. Yan et al. established a simple local coordination number-based descriptor for ORR catalysis based on DFT calculations and suggested that Ni atoms surrounded by the three S nearest neighbors displayed optimal activity [7]. In this work, the ORR/OER catalytic properties of Ni3S2 was investigated based on DFT calculations. Our results show that the Ni3S2(100) surface exhibits the highest ORR and OER catalytic activity among the four studied Ni3S2 surfaces. Furthermore, the ORR catalytic activity of the Ni3S2(100) surface will be further enhanced after doping with Cu atoms and the OER catalytic activity will be improved after the doping of Se. We also developed a materials-related characteristic which serves as an activity descriptor for predicting the ORR and OER catalytic activity, and established volcano relationships between the descriptor and the intrinsic ORR/OER catalytic activities on heteroatom-doped Ni3S2(100) surfaces. The understanding of the ORR/OER catalytic mechanism on the Ni3S2(100) surfaces can provide a powerful design guideline for the development of high-performance ORR and OER electrocatalysts. 2 Computational methods Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [32]. The electron-ion interaction was described using the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [33,34]. The exchange and correlation functional was described by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in the scheme of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [35]. A cut-off energy of 400 eV was adopted for the plane wave basis set, which yields a total energy convergence of 1 meV/atom. The Brillouin zone of the supercells was sampled using a 6 × 6×1 k-point mesh for Ni3S2 slab. The convergence test results for cut-off energy and k-points are shown in the supporting information (Tables S1 and S2). A slab model was used to describe the surface of Ni3S2. A vacuum region of 15 Å was used to avoid the interaction between two periodic units. The ORR and OER are two reverse reactions. The four-electron pathway of the ORR/OER can be written as: (R1) O2(g) + H+ + e− ↔ OOH* (R2) OOH* + H+ + e− ↔ O* + H2O (l) (R3) O* + H+ + e− ↔ OH* (R4) OH* + H+ + e− ↔ H2O(l) + * where * denotes an active site on the surface of the catalyst. The reaction free energy (ΔG) of the elementary steps involved in the ORR and OER processes was calculated based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model developed by Nørskov et al. [36,37], which is widely used in electrochemistry [38–41]. The ΔG can be determined as: ΔG = ΔE + ΔE ZPE − TΔS + ΔG U + ΔG pH, where ΔE is the difference of total energy, ΔE ZPE and ΔS are the differences in the zero-point energy and the change of entropy, T is the temperature (T = 298.15 K in this work), ΔG U and ΔG pH are the contributions from the electrode potential (U) and pH value, which influence the free energy of H+. The calculated E ZPE and S values are summarized in Table S3 of supporting information. The effect of electrode potential on ΔG was quantified as ΔG = neU, where U is the electrode potential, and n is the number of electrons transferred in the elemental steps. The effect of pH on the reaction free energy was calculated as ΔG pH = kTln10 × pH, where k was Boltzmann′s constant. The pH was set as 0 in this work. The theoretical over-potential η can be adopted to determine the activity of the elctrocatalysts. The theoretical over-potential η can be obtained from the reaction free energies for the four elementary steps as η = max[ΔG R1, ΔG R2, ΔG R3, ΔG R4]/e ± 1.23 [V] for ORR and OER. From a thermodynamic viewpoint, a catalyst with a lower overpotential value will have better catalytic performance. There are six stoichiometric nickel sulfide phases in the Ni-S phase diagram, ranging from Ni3S2 to NiS2 in composition. In this work, we focused on the heazlewoodite Ni3S2 phase, where each Ni atom is bound to four S and four Ni nearest-neighbor atoms. Three low index Ni3S2 surfaces were considered here: (100), (110), and (111), as shown in Fig. 1 . Note that two different surface form when Ni3S2 bulk was cleaved along (110) surface, which are denoted as (110)A and (110)B, respectively. The adsorption energy (E ad) of the reaction intermediates on Ni3S2 surfaces was calculated as E ad = E mol-Ni3S2 – E mol – E Ni3S2 [42–44], where the E mol, E Ni3S2, and E mol-Ni3S2 are the total energies of corresponding reaction intermediates, the Ni3S2 surfaces, and adsorption systems, respectively. Based on these definitions, a negative E ad value suggests an exothermic adsorption process. The surface energy (E surf) was extracted from slab calculations: E surf = [E slab – nE bulk]/2A, where A is the area of surface, n is the number of Ni3S2 stoichiometric units contained in the slab, E slab is the total energy of the slab, and E bulk is the total energy of a single Ni3S2 stoichiometric unit as obtained from the calculations on bulk Ni3S2 [45,46]. The factor 1/2 is due to the formation of two surfaces in the slab. For Ni3S2 (110), this calculation gives the surface energy averaged between the two different terminations (110)A and (110)B. 3 Results and discussion In general, surface energy plays an important role in the stability and chemical properties of a material. The smaller the surface energy, the more stable and relatively easier the formation of the corresponding surface. In this work, the surface energies of Ni3S2 were evaluated firstly. As summarized in Table S4 of supporting information, the surface energy of (100) surface is smaller than that of (110) and (111) surfaces, indicating that Ni3S2 (100) surface is the most stable surface among the surfaces investigated here. This is consistent with the coordinate number of the outmost Ni and S atoms in the surface. The smaller the coordinate number, the larger the surface energy. Although the surface energy of (110) surface is the average value of (110)A and (110)B, it also can be predicted that the surface energy of (100) surface is smaller than that of (110)A and (110)B due to the larger coordinate numbers of Ni and S atoms in (100) surface (Table S5 in supporting information). The favorable adsorption energy of reaction intermediate on the surface of a catalyst is a prerequisite for the catalytic reaction. An efficient catalyst should be chemically active enough to activate the reactant and noble enough to release the final product. Before studying the ORR/OER mechanisms, the adsorption properties of reaction intermediates on different surfaces of Ni3S2 are investigated and summarized in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . The adsorption energies of ORR/OER intermediates are closely related to the atomic structure of the Ni3S3 surfaces and the adsorption systems. Generally, the adsorption strength of the reaction intermediates on (111) and (110)A surfaces is stronger than that on the (100) and (110)B surfaces. The adsorption energy of OH increases in the order of (110)B < (100) < (111) < (110)A, and that of O increases as (100) < (110)B < (111) < (110)A. The different adsorption energies of the reaction intermediates on the different surfaces will result in different reaction kinetics. The stronger adsorption strength of the reaction intermediates on the (111) and (110)A surfaces makes it easier to activate the O2 molecule to form OOH, but will have a negative effect on the reduction of O-containing species (O and OH) to form the final product, H2O, which will be confirmed in the following part. Furthermore, OOH only can adsorb on the (100) surface stably with adsorption energy of -1.29 eV, while it directly dissociates to adsorbed O and OH species after structural optimization on the (111), (110)A and (110)B surfaces, which will hinder the process of the oxidation of H2O to O2 (the OER process). Fig. 3 (a) shows the quite different free energy diagrams of ORR/OER on the four Ni3S2 surfaces. When the electrode potential (U) is 0 V, the ΔG values of the RDS for ORR on the Ni3S2 surfaces are calculated to be -0.70, 0.25, 1.86, and -0.58 eV for (100), (111), (110)A, and (110)B, respectively. The overpotential (η) for ORR on the Ni3S2 surfaces are calculated to be 0.53, 1.48, 3.09, and 0.65 V for (100), (111), (110)A, and (110)B, respectively. The overpotential values of ORR on Ni3S2 surfaces increase in the order of (100) < (110)B < (111) < (110)A, indicating that the (100) surface exhibits the highest ORR catalytic activity among the four Ni3S2 surfaces investigated here due to the smallest overpotential, which is comparable to the Pt(111) surface (η is 0.45 V) [36]. It is worth to note that the rate-determining step (RDS) of ORR on Ni3S2 surfaces lies in the reduction of O-containing species: O (R3) or OH (R4). The RDS of ORR on the (100), (111), and (110)A surfaces is located at the fourth elemental step (the reduction of OH to form the final production of H2O, R4) and that on the (110)B surface is the reduction of the O atom to form OH (R3). As the RDS of ORR on Ni3S2 surfaces is always located at the third or fourth coupled proton and electron transfer (CPET) step in the whole ORR process, the weak adsorption strength of ORR intermediates on the (100) and (110)B surfaces makes it easier to break the NiO or NiOH bonds, which results in a lower overpotential value and higher catalytic activity. The OER is the reverse reaction of ORR. They share the same reaction pathways and free energy diagrams. The only difference is the reaction direction. Different from ORR on Ni3S2, the RDS of OER on Ni3S2 is located at the oxidation steps of O (R2) and OOH (R1). As shown in Fig. 3(a), the RDS of OER on the (111), (110)A, and (110)B surfaces is the oxidation of OOH to form the final product of the O2 molecule (R1) and that on the (100) surface is the oxidation of O to form OOH (R2). The ΔG values of the RDS for OER on the Ni3S2 surfaces are calculated to be 1.70, 3.40, 6.42, and 2.07 eV at U = 0 V for (100), (111), (110)A, and (110)B, respectively. The overpotential for OER on Ni3S2 surfaces are 0.47, 2.17, 5.19, and 0.84 V for (100), (111), (110)A, and (110)B, respectively. The Ni3S2 (100) surface also exhibits high catalytic activity for OER, which is comparable with the benchmark of the OER electrocatalyst made up of transition metal oxides, such as IrO2 (η is 0.37 V) and RuO2 (η is 0.56 V) [47,48]. This means that the Ni3S2 (100) surface can exhibit bifunctional catalytic activity toward ORR and OER simultaneously, which is beneficial for use as electrode catalysts in metal-air batteries. This can reduce the cost of ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts and avoid the reduction of conductivity arising from the combination of two different active sites for ORR and OER. Based on the reaction free energy diagram, we can predict the dominant adsorption species on the Ni3S2 (100) surface and understand the ORR and OER processes from the viewpoint of adsorbed species. As shown in Fig. 3(b), when the electrode potential is smaller than 0.70 V, no O-containing species adsorb on the Ni3S2 (100) surface, which is favorable for the adsorption of O2 molecule and then the ORR process, as all elementary steps involved in ORR are exothermic. Water oxidation starts and OH forms on the Ni3S2 (100) surface from 0.70 V. When electrode potential becomes larger than 1.08 V, OH is further oxidized to form adsorbed O atom. At last, when the electrode potential is larger than 1.70 V, OER process is energy favorable and all the O-containing species are oxidized to form O2. Tuning the electronic structure is regarded as an efficient method to improve the activity of electrocatalysts. Doping is one of the promising strategies to manipulate the electronic structure by modifying the composition of the active site [49]. Previous studies have suggested that introducing heterogeneous atoms into the surface of catalysts can significantly modulate their catalytic activity [49–51]. In the following step, in order to further improve the catalytic activity of the Ni3S2 (100) surface, the effect of dopants on the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 surfaces was investigated. Both metallic (Fe, Co, Cu and Ag) and non-metallic (O and Se) atom doping are considered here. As shown in Table 2 , the effect of doped metal atoms on the adsorption energies of ORR intermediates is different and is dependent on the electronic affinity of the heterogeneous atom. The adsorption strength of ORR intermediates increases on the Fe-, Co-, and O-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface due to their smaller electronic affinity compared with Ni and S, while that on Cu- and Ag-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces decreases due to the larger electronic affinity of Cu and Ag. It is interesting to note that the adsorption energy of O on the Se-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface is smaller than that on the pristine Ni3S2 (100) surface, while that of OOH is slightly larger than that on pristine Ni3S2 (100). This will help to reduce the overpotential of OER on the Se-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface and then increase the catalytic activity of OER (Fig. 4 ). Based on the discussion above, it is known that the ORR process on Ni3S2 (100) is determined by the last CPET step (the reduction of OH to form H2O, R4), which means that the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be improved if the adsorption energy of OH is reduced. As shown in Table 2, the adsorption strength of ORR intermediates decreases on the Cu- and Ag-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface, indicating that the catalytic activity of the Ni3S2 (100) surface doped with Cu and Ag should be enhanced. In the following step, we calculated the ORR free energy diagrams of the Ni3S2 (100) surface doped with six heterogeneous atoms. As shown in Fig. 5 , it was found that the ΔG value of the RDS involved in ORR on Cu- and Ag-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface (at electrode potential U = 0 V) decreases to -0.83 and -0.76 eV, respectively. The overpotential of ORR on Cu- and Ag-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces decreases to 0.40 and 0.47 V (Fig. 6 (a)), respectively, which is 0.13 and 0.06 V smaller than that on the pristine Ni3S2 (100) surface. On the contrary, the overpotential of ORR on O-, Co-, and Fe-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface increases to 0.77, 0.96, and 1.36 V due to the stronger adsorption strength of ORR intermediates, indicating worse ORR catalytic activity. The Cu-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits the best ORR catalytic activity due to the favorable adsorption energies of ORR intermediates. A classical volcano relationship was found between the overpotential of ORR and the adsorption energy of OH on Ni3S2 (Fig. 7 (a)). The position of the two legs of the volcano is controlled by the adsorption energy of OH. This is consistent with the Sabatier principle [52–54], which states that the reactants should be adsorbed on the surface of catalyst not too strong or too weak. As summarized in Fig. 6(b), the effect of the doped heterogeneous atoms on the catalytic activity of OER is quite different to that for ORR. Se-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits the highest OER catalytic activity with an overpotential of only 0.25 V, which is 0.21 V smaller than that of pristine Ni3S2 (100). A classical volcano curve was also found for OER (Fig. 7(b)). It is clear that the favorable adsorption energy of OH on the best catalysts for ORR and OER is different. That is the reason why one active center is difficult to catalyze ORR and OER simultaneously. From the analysis above, it is known that the adsorption of ORR/OER intermediates plays an important role in the catalytic activity of Ni3S2. In order to gain further insight into the origin of the adsorption of reaction intermediates on the surface of Ni3S2, the partial density of states (PDOS) projected onto OH adsorbed on the Ni3S2 (100) surface was investigated (Fig. 8 ). It can be found that OH adsorbs on the Ni atom or the doped heterogeneous metal atoms mainly through the hybridization of O-2p states and the d band of the metal atoms. The hybridization becomes stronger on the Co-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface, while that on the Cu-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface becomes weaker, indicating a stronger and weaker adsorption strength of reaction intermediates on Co- and Cu-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces, respectively. Furthermore, it is clear that the d-band shifts to the left as the doped metal varies from Cu to Co. It is known that a left shift of the d-band relative to the Fermi level results in a downward shift of the antibonding states, which results in a weaker adsorption of ORR/OER intermediates. For comparison, the right shift of the d-band relative to the Fermi level will produce more empty orbitals to interact with the reaction intermediates, which will contribute to a stronger adsorption. The left shift of d-band from Cu to Co is consistent with the decreasing of the adsorption energy of OH. Therefore, one conclusion can be made that doping the heterogeneous metal atom into the Ni3S2 crystal lattice can change its surface electronic states and electrocatalytic property significantly. In order to rationally design a catalyst, it is important to understand which intrinsic materials property or descriptor controls the performance of catalysts [55–58]. From the discussion above, it is known that the adsorption energy of OH can act as a descriptor to identify the best ORR and OER catalysts. However, there still lacks a relationship to bridge the gap between the intrinsic properties of the catalyst and the adsorption energy of OH (or the catalytic activity of ORR/OER), which hinders the rational design of catalysts with desirable properties. It is well known that the electron affinity A x, which is defined as the energy given off when a neutral atom gains an extra electron to form a negatively charged ion, represents an intrinsic property of elements. Here, a simple descriptor was introduced: Φ = A x/A Ni for metal atom doping or Φ = A x/A s for non-metal atom doping. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the adsorption energy of OH decreases with the increase of Φ, and a linear relationship is found between them. Plotting the overpotentials of ORR and OER as a function of Φ produces two classical volcano curves (Fig. 9(b) and (c)). Again, Cu and Se are identified as the best dopants in Ni3S2 for ORR and OER, which are consistent with previous results shown in Fig. 7. Therefore, Φ can act as a simple descriptor for Ni3S2 to correlate the catalytic activity with the intrinsic property of materials. The suitability of the descriptor stems from its ability to capture the intrinsic electronic structures of heteroatom-doped Ni3S2. Every element has a unique electronic structure. The doping of heteroatoms results in charge redistribution of the Ni3S2 (100) surface. The effect of the doped heteroatom on the adsorption strength of OH is dependent on the difference between the dopant’s electron affinity and that of Ni or S atoms. As the ORR/OER reaction intermediates prefer to adsorb on a positively charged site, the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates become weak if the electron affinity of the atoms involved in active center increases. This descriptor builds a relationship between the intrinsic properties of the doped Ni3S2 (100) surface and the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, and thus the catalytic activity. This descriptor Φ can provide a helpful guide for designing the material with targeted adsorption properties and enables a quick screening of potential catalysts with high catalytic activity. The HER catalytic activity of heteroatom-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface was also investigated (Fig. 10 (a)). The rate-determining step of HER on Ni3S2 (100) surface is the adsorption of H, the free energy of which was calculated as 0.53 eV and the theoretical overpotential will be 0.53 V. This means that if the adsorption energy of H can be enhanced on Ni3S2 (100) surface, the catalytic activity of HER will be improved. From Table 2, it can be found that the adsorption strength of H on Co- and O-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface is stronger than that on pristine Ni3S2 (100) surface, indicating that the HER catalytic activity of Co- and O-doped Ni3S2 (100) will be enhanced. As shown in Fig. 10(a), the overpotential values of HER are calculated as 0.46, 0.31, 0.73, 0.82, 0.02, and 0.50 V for Fe-, Co-, Cu-, Ag-, O-, and Se-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces, respectively, indicating that O-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits the best HER catalytic activity among the six heteroatoms doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces. This is consistent with recent DFT on Ni3S2 (100) surface, where O-doped Ni3S2 (100) surface also exhibit excellent HER catalytic activity [59]. It is clear that the catalytic activity of HER on O- and Co-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces can enhanced due the stronger adsorption strength of H, while the catalytic activity of HER becomes worse on Cu- and Ag-doped Ni3S2 (100) surfaces due to the weaker adsorption strength of H. Plotting the overpotential value of HER as a function of Φ also produces a classical volcano curve (Fig. 10(b)), indicating that Φ also can be a good descriptor for HER on Ni3S2. In summary, our results show that the Ni3S2 (100) surface excellent bifunctional catalytic activity towards ORR and OER. The ORR catalytic activity of the Ni3S2(100) surface can be further enhanced by the doping of Cu and the OER catalytic activity can be improved by the doping of Se. Recent experimental works have shown that different exposed Ni3S2 surfaces can be synthesized by different synthesis methods and conditions. Feng et al. synthesized the { 2 - 10 } high-index facets in Ni3S2 by direct sulfidization of nickel foam using thiourea as a source of sulfur in a hydrothermal system [25]. Dong et al. synthesized (003)-facet-exposed Ni3S2 nanoporous thin films on nickel foil through anodization and vapor-sulfurization strategies [23]. Kou et al. synthesized Ni3S2 nanosheets with exposed (100) facet by a hydrothermal method [60]. These results indicate that the desired Ni3S2 surface can be attained by the careful selection of suitable methods and synthetic conditions. The future experimental work can be conducted in the field of heteroatom doped Ni3S2 (100) surface for electrocatalysis. We hope that this work can provide a powerful design guideline for the development of high-performance electrocatalysts. 4 Conclusions On the basis of density functional theory, the ORR and OER catalytic mechanism on Ni3S2 surfaces was studied systematically. It is found that the surface structure and doped heterogeneous atoms can significantly influence the electronic structure, and adsorption strength of reaction intermediates, and thus the catalytic activity. We found that this influence can be quantified by a descriptor, which is the difference in electron affinities of the dopant atom and that of the surface. By providing a framework for understanding catalytic activity on the Ni3S2 surface, this work enables the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant materials. coredata.dc:description: Developing highly efficient and nonprecious electrocatalysts for oxygen-involving energy conversion reactions is crucial for the development of clean and sustainable energy technologies. Herein, the intrinsic relationship between the atomic structure and the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 was investigated based on density functional theory. It was found that the Ni3S2 (100) surface exhibits promising bifunctional catalytic activity towards the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The ORR catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be enhanced by the doping of Cu, and the OER catalytic activity of Ni3S2 (100) can be improved by the doping of Se. Furthermore, a descriptor derived from the electron affinity was developed, which correlate Ni3S2 microstructures with their catalytic activities. This study provides a systematic understanding to the intrinsic activity of transition metal sulfides, paving the way to the rational design and development of advanced electrocatalysts for renewable energy technology.
